sect1.title: Configuring the Boot Loader with &yast;
sect1.para: The easiest way to configure general options of the boot loader in your &productname; system is to use the &yast; module. In the &yastcc;, select System Boot Loader. As in , this shows the current boot loader configuration of your system and allows you to make changes.

Use the Boot Loader Installation tab to view and change settings related to type, location and advanced loader settings. To use the &grub2; boot loader, make sure it is selected from the list of available boot loaders.

sect2.title: Adjusting the Default Boot Entry
sect2.para: To change the system that is booted by default, proceed as follows:

step.para: Click Boot Loader Options and open the Default Boot Section list.
Select the desired entry from the list. Note that the > sign in the boot entry name delimits boot section and its subsection.
Click OK to activate these changes.

sect2.title: Modifying the Boot Loader Location
sect2.para: To modify the location of the boot loader, follow these steps:

step.para: Select the Boot Loader Installation tab and then choose one of the following options for Boot Loader Location:

listitem.para: This installs the boot loader in the MBR of the first disk (according to the boot sequence preset in the BIOS).
This installs the boot loader in the boot sector of the / partition (this is the default).
This installs the boot loader in the boot sector of the /boot partition.
This installs the boot loader in the extended partition container.
Use this option to specify the location of the boot loader manually.

step.para: Click OK to apply your changes.

sect2.title: Changing the Boot Loader Time-Out
sect2.para: The boot loader does not boot the default system immediately. During the time-out, you can select the system to boot or write some kernel parameters. To set the boot loader time-out, proceed as follows:

step.para: Open the Boot Loader Installation tab.
Change the value of Time-Out in Seconds by typing in a new value and clicking the appropriate arrow key with your mouse, or by using the arrow keys on the keyboard.
Click OK twice to save the changes.

warning.title: Timeout of 0 Seconds
warning.para: When setting the timeout to 0 seconds, you will not be able to access &grub2; during boot time. When having set the default boot option to a non-Linux operation system at the same time, this effectively disables access to the Linux system.

sect2.title: Configuring Advanced Options
sect2.para: Advanced boot options can be configured via Boot Loader Installation Boot Loader Options. Normally, it should not be necessary to change the default settings.

term.guimenu: Set Active Flag in Partition Table for Boot Partition

listitem.para: Activates the partition that contains the boot loader. Some legacy operating systems (such as Windows 98) can only boot from an active partition.

term.guimenu: Write Generic Boot Code to MBR

listitem.para: Replaces the current MBR with generic, operating system independent code.
Hides the boot menu and boots the default entry.

When checked, the boot menu appears on a graphical splash screen rather than in a text mode. The resolution of the boot screen can be then set from the Console resolution list, and also graphical theme definition file can be specified with the Console theme file-chooser.
If your machine is controlled via a serial console, activate this option and specify which COM port to use at which speed. See info grub or

sect2.title: Changing Boot Loader Type
sect2.para: Set the boot loader type in Boot Loader Installation. The default boot loader in &productname; is &grub2;. To use &grub;, &lilo; or ELILO, proceed as follows:

warning.title: &lilo; is unsupported
warning.para: Using &lilo; is not recommended—it is unsupported on &productname;. Only use it in special cases.

step.para: Select the Boot Loader Installation tab.
In the dialog box that opens, select one of the following actions:

listitem.para: Have &yast; convert the current configuration. When converting the configuration, some settings may be lost.
Write a custom configuration. This action is not available during the installation of &productname;.
Load your own bootloader configuration file. This action is not available during the installation of &productname;.

step.para: Click OK two times to save the changes.

sect2.para: During the conversion, the old &grub2; configuration is saved to the disk. To use it, simply change the boot loader type back to &grub2; and choose Restore Configuration Saved before Conversion. This action is available only on an installed system.

note.title: Custom Boot Loader
note.para: To use a boot loader other than &grub2;, &grub;, or &lilo;, select Do Not Install Any Boot Loader. Read the documentation of your boot loader carefully before choosing this option.
